Authors:
Samuel Chagas Bernardes, Almir R. Pepato, Kristina von
Rintelen, Thomas von Rintelen, Timothy J. Page, Mark de Bruyn
Title:
Change is the Only Constant: The Biogeography of the Indian
Ocean
Keywords:
Vicariance, dispersal, transoceanic, Laurasia, Gondwana,
India, Madagascar, Indo-Australian Archipelago
Abstract:
The Indian Ocean has a complex geological history that has
drawn attention from naturalists for decades. By revisiting previous
studies on multiple taxa, we investigate the biogeographic history of
the Indian Ocean by assessing the relationships among regions of
different geological origins, the possible paths that have connected
these regions, and the relative importance of oceanic dispersal and
continental vicariance. We apply a Bayesian framework to multiple
previously published phylogenetic and phylogeographic datasets. All
phylogenies are time-calibrated and have ancestral areas of distribution
inferred through historical biogeographic methods. Transoceanic
dispersal has predominantly shaped the current biogeographic
configuration for these taxa, with a limited role for vicariance. The
eastern and western Indian Ocean provinces progressively became
connected and India, by receiving immigrants from multiple locations,
has served as an intermediary before its collision with Asia, which may
explain the lack of endemicity found there. The Indian Ocean is a major
highway for organisms, and its complex geological history has enabled
multiple biological routes over time. Long-term taxon exchange between
continents, subcontinents and islands has been commonplace and
ecological opportunities played a major role in the biogeographic
shaping of the Indian Ocean.
